Award.AwardTitle: Probing and manipulating superconductivity in nanostructures
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: Superconductivity can play a significant role in deregulated electricity markets and in lessening carbon dioxide emission and other environmental impacts. The layered structure of high temperature superconductor (HTS) materials result in many dramatic effects in their physical properties especially their current carrying capability, or critical current density, Jc, which is a critical parameter for numerous applications in electrical devices and systems. Raising Jc has been the focus of world-wide efforts in the field of applied superconductivity during the past two decades. In particular, a long-standing question is whether the theoretical depairing limit (Jd) can be reached in practical HTS conductors through self-assembly of nanostructures designed to pin the magnetic vortices. Recent advances in nanoscience have provided fresh opportunities in engineering the microstructures of HTS materials. The approach undertaken in this project of designing physical properties via controlling the charge carriers at the nanoscale represents a leap forward from the traditionally empirical method in which the HTS materials have been developed without a precise guidance of fundamental physics. Such research also provides the forefront of education for the next generation in the fields of nanoscience and material science.

TECHNICAL DETAILS: Controlling microstructure with nanoscale precision has been a major challenge in material research of HTS and other technologically interesting materials due to the difficulties in processing controllably at nanoscale, and the lack of understanding of the physics at such a scale. To address this challenge, several novel processes for strain engineering at the nanoscale have been developed in PI?s group through prior NSF support. In particular, theoretical modeling and numerical simulation have been coherently integrated into this research to provide insights and guidance in nanostructure manipulation and fabrication. The complement of theory and experiment continues in this project provides an efficient approach in understanding the growth mechanism of nanostructures of HTS. Such an understanding is ubiquitous to ultimately achieve the capability to manipulate the nanostructure properties. This research divides into three themes. Theme 1 focuses on investigation of the microscopic growth mechanisms (nucleation, initiation, evolution, etc.) of nanostructures such as aligned arrays of nanotubes and nanorods in HTS YBa2Cu3O7 (YBCO) films. Theme 2 continues focuses on developing theoretical models and numerical simulations to provide insight into the microscopic growth mechanism of nanostructures in YBCO. Extending the modeling and simulation to cover a large range of HTS materials and doping impurities helps explain experimental observations and assists in fabricating nanostructures with specific physical properties. Theme 3 explores superconductivity in graphene. The microscopic transport behavior of massless 2D Dirac fermions in the superconducting state will be studied for a superconductor-graphene-superconductor structure, e.g., Nb-graphene-Nb Josephson junctions. Experimental investigation of the superconductivity in graphene is still in its infancy despite of many exciting theoretical studies. This Nb-graphene-Nb hybrid system may provide a unique system for exploring the physics of the relativistic Josephson effect.

Institution.Name: University of Kansas Center for Research Inc
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF KANSAS CENTER FOR RESEARCH, INC.

Performance_Institution.Name: University of Kansas Center for Research Inc

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall goal of this project was to develop experimental approaches, integrated with theoretical modeling, for controllably engineering the microstructure of high temperature superconducting (HTS) YBa2Cu3O7 (YBCO) films at nanoscales towards 3D magnetic pinning landscape. The main objective of the project was to achieve high current carrying capability approaching the theoretical de-pairing limit in HTS films through nanoscale artificial pinning center engineering in HTS films, which is important to improving cost-performance and therefore to accelerate the commercialization of HTS applications in electrical devices and systems including power transmission cables, transformers, fault-current limiters, motors, generators, and other energy-related applications.

The project has achieved an important understanding of the kinetics and dynamics of the self-assembly processes of the impurity nanostructures during the YBCO film growth. Such an understanding can enable design and synthesis of functional nanostructures in ceramic HTS superconductors for optimal superconducting properties such as electrical current carrying capability in applied magnetic field, and the methodology developed may be applied for many other ceramic materials for implementation of the functional nanostructures through self-assembly processes. Specifically, we have developed an elastic strain model, using which carried out the investigation of the morphology, orientation and dimension of the secondary phase as the artificial pinning centers (APCs) in epitaxial YBCO nanocomposites films has been completed.  This is the first time such studies are done and the results have provided insights on the strain-mediated self-assembly of the APCs in epitaxial ceramic composites. In addition, the modeling enables a search of new APC materials for optimal morphology, orientation and dimension, which can provide the best magnetic vortex pinning in the specific applications. It should be noted that this “material-by-design” approach with theoretical modeling and simulation as guidance differs fundamentally from the current “empirical” approach.    Through a close interaction with modeling effect, we have carried out experiments in demonstrating a control over the morphology, orientation and dimension of APCs in YBCO-based epitaxial nanocomposite films. This result is important not only by exploring new APC approaches to push for better critical current carrying capability in superconductor cables and wires, but also by providing critical feedback as validation of the modeling and prediction.

The key outcomes of this project include 11 invention disclosures, three US patents issued, 65 publications generated with 3 invited book chapters, 11 submitted manuscripts, plus several manuscripts in preparation. In addition, >70 presentations (27 invited/plenary) were given by the PI and her group at regional, national and international workshops and conferences.

This project has provided training in both nanoscience and superconductivity at different levels of post-graduate, graduate and undergraduate. In particular, the research team setting of this project provides highly interactive and dynamic training environment that can benefit the trainees in multiple ways including: 1) team work experience and leadership development; 2) broad knowledge and research skills; and 3) interdisciplinary research approaches. Over the project period, the PI’s group has hosted a large number of researchers at different levels including 12 postdocs, 16 graduate students, 11 undergraduates and 6 high schoolers  on specific topics of superconductor nanocomposite films, graphene-based hybrid devices, graphene fabrication and characterization, and functional ceramic dielectrics, respectively. 8 MS/PhD theses/dissertations were completed with three received honors. All undergraduates have entered PhD programs across the world including Cambridge University, Harvard, UC San Diego, UC Berkeley, University of Wisconsin-Madison, KU, etc.  Students in PI’s lab have also received various awards and honors including Goldwater Scholarship (1), NSF Graduate Fellowship (3 awardees, 1 Honorable Mention), AAUW 2011-12012 dissertation award (1), etc.

This project’s outcome also includes a series education/outreach activities carried out by PI and her group, especially through a collaboration of KU National History Museum Education Director Teresa MacDonald in development of online and hands-on activities for K-12 students/teachers and public. For example, the Science Shorts—a set of four mini animated videos about solar energy and electricity—launched in December 2011 has now had more than 82,000 views at the Quarked! Adventures in the Subatomic Universe website (www.quarked.org), which continues to have visitors from more than 100 countries, and had more than 100,000 unique visits each year. The PI has been an important part of the hands-on outreach program led by the  KU Natural History Museum, which has >5,400 participants during the project period including ~1700 school program participants (school group demographics: 45.3% economically disadvantaged; 6.3% African American, 11.2% Hispanic, 66% white, and 13% other).

 


Last Modified: 08/15/2016
Modified by: Judy Z Wu
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The overall goal of this project was to develop experimental approaches, integrated with theoretical modeling, for controllably engineering the microstructure of high temperature superconducting (HTS) YBa2Cu3O7 (YBCO) films at nanoscales towards 3D magnetic pinning landscape. The main objective of the project was to achieve high current carrying capability approaching the theoretical de-pairing limit in HTS films through nanoscale artificial pinning center engineering in HTS films, which is important to improving cost-performance and therefore to accelerate the commercialization of HTS applications in electrical devices and systems including power transmission cables, transformers, fault-current limiters, motors, generators, and other energy-related applications. The project has achieved an important understanding of the kinetics and dynamics of the self-assembly processes of the impurity nanostructures during the YBCO film growth. Such an understanding can enable design and synthesis of functional nanostructures in ceramic HTS superconductors for optimal superconducting properties such as electrical current carrying capability in applied magnetic field, and the methodology developed may be applied for many other ceramic materials for implementation of the functional nanostructures through self-assembly processes. Specifically, we have developed an elastic strain model, using which carried out the investigation of the morphology, orientation and dimension of the secondary phase as the artificial pinning centers (APCs) in epitaxial YBCO nanocomposites films has been completed. This is the first time such studies are done and the results have provided insights on the strain-mediated self-assembly of the APCs in epitaxial ceramic composites. In addition, the modeling enables a search of new APC materials for optimal morphology, orientation and dimension, which can provide the best magnetic vortex pinning in the specific applications. It should be noted that this "material-by-design" approach with theoretical modeling and simulation as guidance differs fundamentally from the current "empirical" approach. Through a close interaction with modeling effect, we have carried out experiments in demonstrating a control over the morphology, orientation and dimension of APCs in YBCO-based epitaxial nanocomposite films. This result is important not only by exploring new APC approaches to push for better critical current carrying capability in superconductor cables and wires, but also by providing critical feedback as validation of the modeling and prediction. The key outcomes of this project include 11 invention disclosures, three US patents issued, 65 publications generated with 3 invited book chapters, 11 submitted manuscripts, plus several manuscripts in preparation. In addition, >70 presentations (27 invited/plenary) were given by the PI and her group at regional, national and international workshops and conferences. Over the project period, the PI?s group has hosted a large number of researchers at different levels including 12 postdocs, 16 graduate students, 11 undergraduates and 6 high schoolers on specific topics of superconductor nanocomposite films, graphene-based hybrid devices, graphene fabrication and characterization, and functional ceramic dielectrics, respectively. 8 MS/PhD theses/dissertations were completed with three received honors. All undergraduates have entered PhD programs across the world including Cambridge University, Harvard, UC San Diego, UC Berkeley, University of Wisconsin-Madison, KU, etc. Students in PI?s lab have also received various awards and honors including Goldwater Scholarship (1), NSF Graduate Fellowship (3 awardees, 1 Honorable Mention), AAUW 2011-12012 dissertation award (1), etc. This project?s outcome also includes a series education/outreach activities carried out by PI and her group, especially through a collaboration of KU National History Museum Education Director Teresa MacDonald in development of online and hands-on activities for K-12 students/teachers and public. For example, the Science Shorts—a set of four mini animated videos about solar energy and electricity—launched in December 2011 has now had more than 82,000 views at the Quarked! Adventures in the Subatomic Universe website (www.quarked.org), which continues to have visitors from more than 100 countries, and had more than 100,000 unique visits each year. The PI has been an important part of the hands-on outreach program led by the KU Natural History Museum, which has >5,400 participants during the project period including ~1700 school program participants (school group demographics: 45.3% economically disadvantaged; 6.3% African American, 11.2% Hispanic, 66% white, and 13% other).
